content.description: This sits on the obvious sharp and slightly overhanging arete right next to the walk up trail. Nice moves and a good top-out make for a great little problem.

This is a SDS to

Southern Bulge

.

The Flagstaff bouldering guidebook says to start on "opposing sidepull/undercling crimps." The right hand crimp is obvious. For the left hand, strong climbers have used both the obvious 1 pad sidepull/flake just above the left toe hueco as well as a smaller crimp a bit higher. The lower sidepull is the more intuitive start IMO but very scrunched if you're tall.

8a.nu grades

.

Lower sidepull beta:

https://vimeo.com/16207095

.

Higher crimp beta:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mx9TAZqG3sA

and

https://vimeo.com/99060369

.
This is fun and has a nice, flat landing. The first move is the crux. The V2 variation uses a right hand on a bigger knob out right. There is a V8 sit start as well?
content.location: This ascends the Southern bulge of South North Rock. It starts with opposed hands, chest high. Move your right hand to a big dish, then left bump to a sidepull. Next, move your right hand to a cool, smooth "football" rock. Top out on pockets to slab. Walk off the back.

content.description: Climb the protruding knobs, very different for a MN guy.
content.location: Go up the center of the right rock.

content.description:
Start sitting well underneath the crack in between North Rock and Right Rock (the downhill boulder). Get in the crack, and figure out how to turn the lip to an easy finish.

I doubt I did the FA, but I've never heard anyone else talk about it. It's fun if you're into that sort of thing.
content.location:
This is just right of the

Southwest Arête V3

and Drill Pig.

content.description: Climb edges on the upper boulder.
content.location:
This climbs north of

Arete

, V2 right off the trail.

content.description:
This starts uphill from the

East Side Lower Traverse

and is a logical continuation of that problem.  A little more engaging than the lower traverse, this one follows round cobbles across a steep face.  Top out on the right side of the wall.
content.location: This is on the East Face of the higher of the 2 North Rocks.

content.description:
This is the traverse on the East side of the lower rock.  It is pretty much the easiest problem to climb on around these boulders, therefore a prime candidate for a little stretching/warm up....  Start down left and work your way across the giant jugs and big loose cobbles for the feet.  Finish up the arete on the right.  If you loved the crappy rock but it was too easy, continue traversing right onto the

East Side Upper Traverse

....
content.protection: It's not too high, but the crux is turning the corner at the end where the landing is the worst.... Don't fall.
content.location:
Walk up the trail past the

Pebble Boulder

toward the

Red Wall

.  This is on the East side of the lower North Rock.
